Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative research: Turbulent cascades and regularity theory in physical scales of 3D incompressible fluid flows
Award.AbstractNarration:
Grujic, DMS-1212023
Dascaliuc, DMS-1211413

The investigators aim to advance our understanding of the phenomenon of turbulence, as well as to offer new insights into the problem of possible singularity formations in 3D viscous incompressible fluids described by the 3D Navier-Stokes equations (NSE). The project extends their recent results regarding existence and locality of energy cascades, and anomalous dissipation in physical scales of the flow. The main goals are, on one hand, to present Onsager-critical Morrey-type conditions preventing anomalous dissipation in 3D incompressible flows and to discover a set of universal scaling laws -- reminiscent of the fundamental Kolmogorov K41 laws -- that naturally transpire from their theory of turbulent cascades in physical scales, and on the other hand, to present mathematical evidence of a geometric scenario closing the scaling gap in the regularity problem, that is, of the criticality of the 3D NSE problem for large data. The key idea is to use a new ensemble-averaging process capable of detecting significant sign fluctuations of the physical density of interest at the given scale. This approach is highly local in space and is applicable to flows that do not satisfy homogeneity and isotropy assumptions. In addition, it provides a framework for the study of geometrically coherent structures in physical space.

In 2000, the Clay Mathematical Institute identified seven "Millennium Problems" in mathematics, solutions to which would have a broad impact on society in the 21st century. One of these problems is the task of providing a rigorous mathematical foundation (namely, addressing the possibilities of singularity formations) for the Navier-Stokes equations that describe the motion of fluids. Existence of singularities is a fundamental issue for mathematical modeling of any real-life phenomenon. In the case of Navier-Stokes equations this regularity problem is believed to be linked with the notion of turbulence. Despite successes in empirical modeling and computational techniques used to study turbulence, this phenomenon remains one of the unresolved fundamental problems of modern physics. Any measurable progress in understanding turbulence can have a broad impact in such areas as weather and climate modeling and engineering applications. On one hand, suppressing turbulence is essential in designing and engineering more efficient vehicles, wind turbines, pipeline systems. On the other hand, enhancing turbulent mixing is desired in a variety of nano-scale engineering designs, as well as in biomedical engineering -- one example being more efficient drug delivery systems. The project helps advance understanding of how to better predict and detect turbulent behavior, as well as possibly control it. The investigators engage graduate and undergraduate students in the project and present lectures on turbulence to local high school students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This Project aimed to advance our understanding of turbulence in physical scales via a suitable ensemble-averaging process, as well as its impact on the regularity theory of the Navier-Stokes Equations -- one of the seven "Millennium Problems" in mathematics. 

The Project provided opportunity for collaboration with colleagues from several universities, and produced over 20 lectures in venues starting from local undergraduate student conferences to international research meetings. It resulted in 6 peer-reviewed publications with more planned in the near future. It actively involved two undergraduate and three graduate students, including one from the underrepresented groups in Mathematics.

Turbulence is a part of everyday life. Reducing turbulent effects is crucial in designing efficient vehicles and pipelines.  Enhancing turbulent mixing is important in developing new effective drug delivery systems. And considering effects of turbulent energy transport is instrumental in weather and climate modeling.  Our lack of understanding of the mathematical mechanisms behind turbulence forces us to solve these important engineering and modeling problems largely by trial and error, building on mounting experimental data and numerical simulations of ad-hoc turbulence models. Any real progress in understanding the mathematics behind turbulence will have a considerable impact on reducing engineering R&D costs and well as increasing precision of the new scientific models and improving safety and effectiveness of new engineered devices.

There is a feedback effect as well. The rich set of empirical data from trials in wind tunnels and water tanks, and, of course, numerical simulations can also guide us towards a pathway to solve the mathematical issues involved.

This Project targets the core of all these issues by investigating the interplay between the underlying equations of fluid motion and the empirical theory of turbulence.

The results are encouraging. For example, our theorems about turbulent cascades in physical space provide a simple method of monitoring turbulence (more precisely, the strength and the width of the energy cascade) simply by measuring global energy and enstrophy. (Measuring these, however, may present a technical challenge depending on the application.)

The effects of external forcing on turbulence that we discovered may, in principle, lead to development of turbulence-control mechanisms by controlling the size of external forcing (although our understanding of how the shape of the force affects turbulence is far from being complete at this point).

Our investigation of formation of coherent structures, like vortex tubes, and their effect on global energy and enstrophy of fluid flow, has a potential to enhance weather modeling.??Mathematically, our new approach to averaging in turbulence, being inherently local and more conducive to study of geometrical structures within the flow, hints at a new way of attacking the Navier-Stokes regularity problem itself. In particular, our rigorous results connecting vortex stretching to criticality, as well as the corresponding energy-enstrophy bounds, point to the vortex stretching as the possible mechanism for anisotropic energy dissipation that may be instrumental in preventing singularity formation, thus connecting physics of turbulence with mathematics of the equations of motion.

Our research on the stochastic theory of multiplicative cascades underlying Navier-Stokes Equations helps develop yet another novel approach to tackle the regularity problem, as well as provides additional insight on the dynamics of energy transfer processes in the solutions.

In addition, our averaging technique has a potential to serve as a basis for new type of highly efficient numerical methods using domain discretization induced by our K1K2-coverings. Such numerical methods would greatly improve the quality of numerical simulations of any model featuring turbulent-like energy transport.

And finally, the methods we developed to study turbulence via space-time localization and ensemble averaging of the Navier-Stokes equations, may provide new methodology for studying complex, chaotic systems by using suitably modified versions of our averaging. ?Naturally, this Project opened new questions for future investigations and we are confident our results will contribute both to mathematical theory of turbulence and to a number of other areas of science, technology, and even daily human activity.
